body:
If we're doing the 'remember last kernel' thing, which I'm still not 100% convinced by, I think it should be obvious on the button which kernel you'll get, without having to hover to see a tooltip.

With #6874 merged, it could be stored in the config system rather than using localstorage.

> I think it should be obvious on the button

I agree, and I think the kernel logo is the way to do that. With the kernel logo not merged, I didn't include it. Let's finish that one up, and I'll see what I can do with it here.

I'm fine with deferring it until after we can see it with logos, but I think the word will be needed in addition to the logo. Especially since kernels may be missing a logo (is that R for R, Ruby or Rust?), and you may have multiple kernels with the same logo (Python 3 vs 2, kernels in different environments, etc.)

I put the kernel display name in the dropdown:

![screen shot 2014-11-15 at 13 09 46](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/151929/5059242/c2df8760-6cc8-11e4-8dd2-b2569a01795f.PNG)
I quite like that. It gives a bigger click target to select another kernel, too.
Looks like I've borked something in kernel start, resulting in extra kernels. I'll look into that.
I added a new 'new notebook' action, but never unbound the old one, so clicking the button made two notebooks. Fixed.

At first launch the dropdown menu button  is empty (well just the arrow), I guess it shouldn't.

I'm still not convinced, as I cannot launch a julia notebook without making it the default.
So basically you just have two new notebook button, one of which is a dropdown.

What about something like  the following:

![capture d ecran 2014-11-17 a 11 39 39](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/335567/5068443/b74b5942-6e4e-11e4-99a5-7cee479e0641.png)

Where click on the full line launch the notebook, and click on the star (I'm open to change star to something else) make the kernel default.

Or have a click on current dropdown not launch new notebook (which still don't really solve anything)

Updated based on feedback:
- selection is stored in frontend-config instead of localStorage
- kernelspec model is now a dict, with the server-side's default kernel selection included. This is used to set the initial value.
- a check is used to indicate which is the default. Clicking the checkbox changes the selection and doesn't start a new notebook:

![select-r](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/151929/5077978/420cdeee-6e5d-11e4-8034-6eb13731f48f.png)

![julia-selected](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/151929/5077980/456d27b0-6e5d-11e4-879f-6298e4ea2f22.png)
- Clicking the name starts a new notebook, and doesn't change the current selection:

![new notebook](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/151929/5077992/5eb4aa7c-6e5d-11e4-9458-f3a832b0eb96.png)

I like it. 
@minrk you didn't really gave your feeling. It is still quite different from what you had in mind.

IMO, the selection boxes are confusing. Tooltips clear it up, but it's not obvious to me what they mean _until_ I hover over the checkboxes and even then I'd have to do double-take. Probably worth noting that I :heart: the original screenshot in this PR (way up top). Picking the default is a separate issue to me for another PR.
The problem with the top screenshot is that it do both start a notebook and select the default, and there is no way to do one without the other.
Marking as design review and ping @ellisonbg.

Another alternative:

![screenshot from 2014-11-18 10 34 53](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/327925/5093580/a4f24466-6f0e-11e4-85eb-ff6ea81ec0d8.png)

Change default would simlpy bring up a dialog where you have the same set of options in a dropdown.

I might use a star or something instead of the bullet point so that it doesn't imply that it works like radio buttons. I couldn't immediately see how to get that in Balsamiq, though.
If we go that way, I'm not sure it needs a mark, since the current default is displayed next to New Notebook already.

- I like the idea of separating the last selected kernel from the default
  one and storing that information in the server side config.
- I think a checkbox in the dropbox is a solid expression of "use this as
  the default" (a star is another options, but it has a bit of a "favorite"
  connotation here which isn't quite right). I think that the checkbox, even
  with no tooltip, is going to be more discoverable to users that other UI
  expressions of the "pick this one as the default" action.
- But I do agree with Kyle that even with the tooltip, the discoverability
  of what the checkbox does is weak. I think we should try to improve that.
  What about adding some text or visual indicator at the top of the checkbox
  column that signifies these are for picking the default. A down arrow
  pointing at the checkbox column followed by the text "Default"?

I'm fine with either. The change default might need a dialog at least which I think is over kill. At some point we might want a "manage kernels" page also.

Anyway as long as I can :
- open a new notebook with specified kernel (without changing default)
- change the default (without openin g notebook)

I'm fine with it.

Envoyé de mon iPhone

> Le 18 nov. 2014 à 19:41, Min RK notifications@github.com a écrit :
> 
> If we go that way, I'm not sure it needs a mark, since the current default is displayed next to New Notebook already.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

> What about adding some text or visual indicator at the top of the checkbox
> column that signifies these are for picking the default.

That's making a single dropdown a full-fledged multi-column table with headings. It's going to be unreasonably wide if the title is more than one or two characters:

![screen shot 2014-11-18 at 11 37 29](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/151929/5094673/cd60dd96-6f17-11e4-8495-14c68f700780.PNG)

If we want columns with headings, I think a dropdown is the wrong way to go, and it should be put in a dialog or separate preferences page. I don't actually like either option, but I think that's where it should go if columns and headings are required.
If the title is just 'Default', and in a slightly smaller font, I could imagine it looking  reasonable.

I don't like the header. The 'default' also appear in the button that open the dropdown and the check symbol is in front of it. That really seem to me like a strong indication of what the default is.

And this is also the desing that is used in native dropdown to mark the selected default value
![capture d ecran 2014-11-19 a 08 39 50](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/335567/5102242/ae524b1e-6fc7-11e4-89ae-3e5365fdb25f.png)

Wait, I can order a Mercedes SLK through IPython??!?

Now that's brand engagement.

- I can't wait until we have the Mercedes dropdown, although I am probably
  partial to Porsche as the default.
- The column heading doesn't really work too well. Might be better with
  just the text "Default" in a more subtle visual treatment.
- At this point, I think the best option is the plain checkbox+tooltip
  approach.

wrote:

> 
> Now that's brand engagement.

Brian E. Granger
Cal Poly State University, San Luis Obispo
@ellisonbg on Twitter and GitHub
bgranger@calpoly.edu and ellisonbg@gmail.com
Just throwing an idea out there, why not just persist the last selected kernel?  Then we don't have to argue about stars, dots, checkboxes, etc...

> Just throwing an idea out there, why not just persist the last selected kernel? Then we don't have to argue about stars, dots, checkboxes, etc...

That's exactly what this PR did when I opened it.

> That's exactly what this PR did when I opened it.

I prefer that!

@jdfreder: @Carreau doesn't like that behaviour, and I partly agree with him, which is why we're toying with various ideas to have some notion of a default kernel as distinct from the last one started.

I still think it might be better to have a separate menu entry 'change default', which brings up a dialog. It's not as visually neat as having both 'start' and 'set default' actions in the same dropdown, but it avoids any confusion from using UI in unfamiliar ways. And I imagine that for most people, changing the default kernel will be a fairly rare action, since it's so easy to use a non-default one.
We could even have _zero_ UI for changing the default for now, and only allow editing config directly, either the json file or in the js console. The initial value is still configurable server-side.

> We could even have zero UI for changing the default for now, and only allow editing config directly, either the json file or in the js console. The initial value is still configurable server-side.

That suits me.

That's OK by me. But if we think we might add ui to change it later, that
implies it should be configured in frontend config, which we've said people
shouldn't need to edit by hand. Not sure what to do about that.

I am fine with having the UI simply remember the last selected kernel for
now (not having the ability to pick the default explicitly).

On Tue, Nov 25, 2014 at 8:31 AM, Thomas Kluyver notifications@github.com
wrote:

> That's OK by me. But if we think we might add ui to change it later, that
> implies it should be configured in frontend config, which we've said people
> shouldn't need to edit by hand. Not sure what to do about that.
